policyActions.notes:
No evidence of specific policies for the protection of the elderly. Reports state that compliance with existing regulations is very poor.

"Authorities continue to impose social-distancing measures requiring individuals to stay at least 2 meters (6.5 feet) away from each other, and people must wear face coverings in public; however, there is widespread noncompliance with COVID-19 measures. Some commercial venues are allowed to operate, including gyms, shopping centers, and restaurants. Officials are keeping other establishments, such as museums, closed. Some schools have reopened. Intercity and interstate travel continues to be allowed. Private vehicles may drive with a maximum of four passengers. Public transport services have resumed. Regional variation regarding restrictions is possible, dependent on local caseload. Additional measures could be introduced in the coming weeks to curb the spread of COVID-19."

https://archive.vn/kyTO5

policyActions.notes:
The Ministry of Education posted a Press Release on their Facebook page on the 31st December, regarding “Reopening of School for 2020/2021 Easter Term”.
“The Department of Education wishes to advise the general public that all government schools will reopen for instruction on Monday, 4th January, 2021 as follows:
Due to the current Emergency Powers Orders, students on the islands of New Providence, Abaco, Eleuthera and Exuma will not report to a school site but will log in to their school via the Department of Education’s virtual learning platform to attend school virtually. Students on all the other islands will report to their school campus for face-to-face instruction.” Source: https://archive.vn/X1whq

policyActions.notes:
As of Dec. 31, authorities in Guatemala have amended the entry requirements for international travelers, which are part of the nation's ongoing coronavirus disease (COVID-19) response. All travelers aged 10 and over must still present a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or antigen test taken up to 96 hours before travel instead of 72 hours. Additionally, international air travelers who do not have proof of a negative test may be permitted entry only if they have proof of having taken a test before travel and were not able to receive their results in time for their arrival, or if they can demonstrate the need to urgently travel to Guatemala. Travelers in these categories will be tested upon arrival at La Aurora International Airport (GUA) and must remain in the airport while awaiting results.

https://web.archive.org/web/20210104020831/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/424081/guatemala-authorities-revise-covid-19-testing-requirements-for-international-travelers-as-of-dec-31-update-26

policyActions.notes:
The Guyanese government announced on December 31st that they would be distributing $2 Billion GYD (9,585,880 USD) to all public servants. Each of the 60 000 recipients will receive $25 000 GYD. This was coded on December 31 as it is not clear when the money will be distributed. Additionally, it was coded as E3 not E1 as it is not income support to all formal workers, only those who work for the Guyanese government. 
sources: https://archive.vn/iQY2c
https://archive.vn/9BvJA
https://archive.vn/9g1b8

policyActions.notes:
Public transport in all regions and cities is operating in compliance with sanitary measures. No restrictions on public transport are reported. 
Link: https://archive.vn/faLhH

There is no "stay at home" policy announced in regions and cities. 
Link: https://archive.vn/faLhH
No update

On December 31, the exemption of businesses from 3 types of taxes came to an end. The Government has not provided any comments on the extension of tax relief for businesses. 
Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201027160302/https://www.orbitax.com/news/archive.php/Kazakhstan-Introduces-Addition-43092

From 18 January, schools will be opened for Grades 1, 5, 9, and 11 in Bishkek. This policy is relevant until February 1. It should be noted that the decision to close or open schools are made by local administrations based on epidemiological situations locally. 
Link: https://archive.vn/rl0pG

Kindergartens are still closed in Bishkek. It will be opened from January 20. Workplace closure is made by local governments based on the epidemiological situation locally. 
Link: https://rus.azattyk.org/a/31038275.html
No restriction on public events was reported. The election will take place on January 10.

policyActions.notes:
"Initially, vaccinations will be available to senior residents aged 75 or over, living either in care homes or in the community, who have received a letter from the Government inviting them to contact the COVID-19 Call Centre"

https://web.archive.org/web/20210115170152/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/First-COVID-19-vaccination-in-Principality

In general:

Vaccines will become available gradually, and so the Prince’s Government has had to establish priorities to ensure that at-risk groups are at the front of the queue. These groups are:

-Elderly people living in care settings

-People aged over 75

-People aged 65–74

-People with underlying health conditions (obesity (BMI>30), particularly among younger people, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory disease, complex high blood pressure disorders, heart disease, type 1 or type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, recent history of cancer (within the last three years), solid organ transplant or haematopoietic stem cell transplant, Down’s syndrome, etc.)

-Healthcare workers, etcA

The vaccination campaign will therefore be rolled out in several phases to target each category of the population.

https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165719/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/

Required at all times outside the home

policyActions.notes:
All education and training activities for public schools will continue via distance education.
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Movie theaters, coffee houses, tea gardens, soccer fields, internet/electronic game halls, billiard halls, swimming pools, Turkish baths, saunas, massage salons are suspended. Shopping malls, supermarkets, barbers, and hairdressers will only be open for service during the hours of 10:00 – 20:00. Dining establishments such as restaurants, patisseries, cafes, and cafeterias will no longer be open for in-person dining and will be offering delivery services between 10:00 and 20:00.
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Starting with 12th of September, a ban on concerts and festivals in public spaces has been introduced.
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/CTqsq
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/CTqsq
policyActions.policy_value_display_field: Restrictions on gatherings of 10 or fewer people

policyActions.notes:
Busses, ferries, and trains are operating, but there are limits to passenger capacity on buses and all passengers must wear a mask. 
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Turkish citizens and residents are subject to a four-day curfew from 9 PM on Thursday, 31st of December 2020 through 5 AM on Monday, 4th of January 2021.
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Turkish citizens and residents are subject to a four-day curfew from 9 PM on Thursday, 31st of December 2020 through 5 AM on Monday, 4th of January 2021. Foreigners in the country temporarily for tourism are exempt from curfews and travel permit requirements.
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Starting with 30th of December, all travelers who arrive in Turkey through air, land or sea will be asked to present a negative PCR test result document issued 72 ours prior to arrival. Those who fail to do so at the border gate or seaport will be quarantined in the address to where they are going. Travelers who arrived in Turkey from United Kingdom, Denmark or South Africa in the past 10 days will be asked to present a negative test result done within the past 72 hours, and also will be required to quarantine in the address to where they are going.
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Since the start of the pandemic, Ankara has sent medical supplies to 156 countries and 11 international organizations, said Recep Tayyip Erdogan in his New Year message.

https://web.archive.org/web/20210127163036/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/turkey/adopt-measures-on-new-years-eve-erdogan-urges-nation/2094586

Ministry of Health updated on 3rd of September 2020 “COVID 19 Guide” (including “COVID-19 Outbreak Management and Study Guide”, “General Information, Epidemiology and Diagnosis”, “Infection, Control and Isolation” materials).
Links: https://archive.fo/NCoEa

PCR testing for foreigners is limited to those who have symptoms, or those who may have an entry requirement back to their home country. Testing is paid for by the traveler.
https://archive.fo/3dmIF

Starting with 8th of September, citizens are obliged to wear masks without exception in all areas (public areas, avenues, streets, parks, gardens, public transportation vehicles, workplaces) across the country, excluding residences. 
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/QF9El and https://archive.fo/wip/s79gn
policyActions.policy_value_display_field: Required at all times outside the home

policyActions.notes:
Turkish citizens and residents aged 65 and older are restricted to their place of residence, and only allowed outside between 10:00 and 13:00. Also, for the same category, Intercity travel permits are required.
Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

policyActions.notes:
For the purpose of 2020 fiscal year only, the government has created a stand-alone budgetary program under the Finance Ministry to fight the pandemic. This program allows for a greater flexibility in the reallocation of funds to quickly accommodate changing priorities. As of end-year, UAH 66.5 billion out of UAH 80.9 billion of appropriated funds were spent, or 82 percent. In parallel, as of early December, local budgets spent UAH 4.4 billion on the purchase of COVID-related equipment and services, and the National Health Service disbursed UAH 10.6 billion to finance top-ups to health care personnel treating patients with COVID. 

https://web.archive.org/web/20210116200914/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
